etymology.description: Semantic: 入(入) (rù, 'enter') + Phonetic: 肉(肉) (ròu, 'meat') = to penetrate flesh -> vulgar for 'fuck'
etymology.interpretation: The character combines 入(入) (rù, 'enter') symbolizing insertion, and 肉(肉) (ròu, 'meat') referring to the physical body, effectively conveying the explicit concept in a straightforward manner.

examples.chinese: 他跟人吵架时(他跟人吵架時)，用了‘肏’这个词(用了‘肏’這個詞)。
examples.pinyin: Tā gēn rén chǎojià shí, yòngle ‘cào’ zhège cí.
examples.english: He used the word 'cào' when he quarreled with someone.

examples.chinese: 别跟他开玩笑了(別跟他開玩笑了)，他总喜欢肏别人(他總喜歡肏別人)。
examples.pinyin: Bié gēn tā kāi wánxiào le, tā zǒng xǐhuān cào biérén.
examples.english: Don't joke with him; he always likes to 'cào' others.

examples.chinese: 听说他在夜店肏了很多人(聽說他在夜店肏了很多人)！
examples.pinyin: Tīngshuō tā zài yèdiàn cào le hěn duō rén!
examples.english: It is said that he 'cào'd many people at the nightclub!
